awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Award: Plant and Rhizosphere Processes that Prevent Groundwater Contamination from Metals and Nitrates
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at North Carolina A&T University will develop sustainable technological solutions to current and emerging agricultural and urban environmental problems to protect water resources and increase agricultural productivity. The project will actively engage underrepresented students in interdisciplinary research, while building a strong relationship with the local high school community.

The intermittent application of carbon-rich food processing wastewater to soil for treatment can create saturated and anaerobic conditions or aerobic conditions and lead to mobilization of redox-sensitive soil native metals or nitrate. The goal of the project is to evaluate plant and rhizobial processes important to reduce mobilization of metal and nitrate to groundwater during land application of carbon-rich food processing wastewater. This project will use column studies to evaluate evapotranspiration, rhizostimulation, plant uptake, oxygenation and phytosequestration. It utilizes analysis of soil, water and plant samples, and measurement of soil oxidation-reduction potential, soil moisture and soil microbial communities. The research identifies the role of individual rhizobial and plant-processes towards nitrate and metal mobilization in laboratory scales. The research results are important for development of plant-based engineering solutions to reduce land treatment system problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Land application of food processing wastewater (FPW), a common practice, can create continuously saturated and anaerobic soil conditions. Such conditions can mobilize soil native metals including arsenic, lead and iron, leaching of those metals can pollute groundwater. Alternatively, ammonium and organic nitrogen present in the wastewater can be converted to nitrate under the presence of oxygen and the nitrate can pollute the groundwater. Therefore, the goal of the project was to utilize phytoremediation for solving nitrate and metal mobilization in the land where wastewater is applied for the treatment. We studied soil-plant-rhizosphere processes when poplar plants are used for phytoremediation of food processing wastewater.

The experiment used two column experiments, small and large soil column experiment, to answer research questions. Activities included application of wastewater to the poplar planted soils and no-plant soils, collection and measurement of leachate, analysis of leachate water quality for metals and nitrogen species, measurement of soil redox and moisture using sensors, and analysis of soils and plants for metals and nitrogen, and analysis of soils for microbial biomass and diversity.

The results indicated that both treatment (poplar trees) and the control reduced carbon in the wastewater in the range of 65-70%. Plants acted like oxygen pumps as the oxidation reduction potential (ORP), which affects metal and nitrate mobilization, was increased. Increased ORP reduces the metal mobilization in general and may be nitrate as well. Microbial communities were significantly enhanced by poplar plantation in terms of diversity. Plants successfully accumulated metals in roots from soil with an accumulation factor of greater than 40 for some metals and translocated to shoots from roots with a translocation factor greater than 10. Crop coefficient was 1.88 indicating accelerated loss of water in planted columns. The results demonstrated the benefit of plants in creating more oxic conditions, removing more wastewater from rhizosphere, accumulating and translocating metals in the biomass, and enhancing rhizodegradation of pollutants by microbial population enhancement. The knowledge of the soil-plant-microbial processes is useful in designing engineered phytoremediation systems.

The project trained two graduate and four undergraduate students in research. Five of the six students were from underrepresented minority community thus helping prepare and produce graduates of color. A teaching module on land application of wastewater for treatment was designed and implemented in ecological engineering course. Finally, the research results were disseminated at diverse avenues including conference presentations, thesis, and research journal.
